thread.title_full: Foster families honored during appreciation week - Sun Sentinel

author: Jan Engoren
title: Foster families honored during appreciation week
text:
Last year the Florida Senate passed a bill designating the second week of February as Foster Family Appreciation Week, encouraging the Department of Children and Families, local governments and other agencies to sponsor events to promote awareness of the contributions made by foster families to the state.
According to figures provided by ChildNet, an agency that administers the child welfare system in Palm Beach and Broward counties and throughout the state, foster families have provided more than 6,000 children with foster families and adoptions.
"Foster parents make an immeasurable and lifelong impact on the lives of our community's most vulnerable children by simply providing safety, stability and, most importantly, love," said ChildNet spokesman Kenny Brighton. "While being a foster parent is not always easy, foster parents are never alone as they receive constant support and assistance from local agencies, nonprofits and other foster parents."
Earlier this month, ChildNet honored foster families including Kimberly Carty, a single mother in Boca Raton who took in two girls as infants and later adopted them; a couple in Riviera Beach, who fostered 10 infants and toddlers; and Carl and Diana Geren, both 51, of Boynton Beach, who recently adopted their former foster child, Alexander Magestae, now 3 1/2.
Since becoming foster parents in 2007, the Gerens have provided a home for 14 foster children.
After learning about Kids in Distress, an agency that works with at-risk children and families, Diana Geren, originally from Colombia, contacted them, signed up for free classes and learned about the need for foster families.

"We fell in love with the program," she said.
"The classes were a real highlight," Carl Geren said. "We couldn't wait to go each week and hear the many stories about all the kids. They taught us a lot, including how to interact with the kids and how to react to certain situations. It was really interesting."
Speaking of their new son, who is of Haitian descent, Diana Geren said, "He is our sunshine; he's adorable and so smart. He's bilingual – we speak Spanish at home – and very friendly."
"Having a child from a different race is a learning experience," she said. "But, like any child, they need love, need to be cuddled and made to feel secure. He gets attached to the other foster children we bring in and always wants to keep them."
And Carl Geren, who has a 21-year-old son from his first marriage, said, "He's no different than my biological son."
Do the Gerens have any advice for prospective foster or adoptive parents?
"Have patience," Carl Geren said. "And do your homework and be prepared. These kids need love, caring and a family. Once you're in a home with other people, you become a family."
Diana Geren advises to put the interest of the foster child above your own.
"Sometimes you need to shift your mindset," she said. "It's our job to support and help them when they need it, and learn to let go, if need be."
"Also, realize you're not alone," she said. "The agency will help you each step with training and continuing education. There's a lot of help available."
Visit ChildNet.us or call 561-352-2500.
